content.description: This overlooked classic was the first route that went up on this formation and it is just plain fun!   The crux is probably turning the corner at the squeeze, no worries the gear is good.    New traditional leaders need to get on this route.
content.location: Located on the northwest face, STP shares the first 10 feet with Just Say No. Climb the low angle ramp passing under the golden overhang and squeeze to gain a sweet vertical hand crack.

climbs.name: Kate
climbs.fa: Ron and Shari Yahne  1988 Ground Up

content.description: Scramble up some talus then face climb to a small pine tree which hides a nice vertical crack. Climb vertical line to where it meets a ledge (Crux), from here go left through the overhanging V-slot to anchors.
content.location: Shares the start with Flesh for Lulu, right of the major overhanging dihedral.   Shares anchors with Squeeze to Please and Flesh for Lulu

climbs.name: Just Say No
climbs.fa: Ron and Shari Yahne  1989 Ground Up

content.description: Get your mind right for this one. Ron recently climbed this route again after MANY years and told me “that thing is kind of  Spicy! Dang I was pretty bold back in the day!”
content.protection: .3-#2 Cammalot, stoppers,1 bolt   Bolted anchors at top
content.location: The start of this route is located jus left of a large golden overhang on the north west face of the formation. Climb a low angle ramp to the base of a major right facing dihedral, follow this up and right until the gold rock band. Clip the bolt to your left and continue to climb a spicy face to gain the crack. Following the crack for about 30 feet you will reach a foot traverse that leads to the right and to the anchors.

climbs.name: Flesh for Lulu
climbs.fa: Ron and Shari Yahne, Vernon Phinney, 1988 Ground Up

content.description: Get your hard hat and gloves on for this one! Definitely Blue Collar !   Scramble up and left through some easy terrain to gain a large flake. From here head up the dihedral through an overhanging V-slot to anchors.
content.location: This is the offwidth crack in the smaller dihedral right of Squeeze to Please.

content.description: The route goes up the northeast face of Oval Office, to the right of a plant -filled steep gully. After a few hard opening moves and several horizontal breaks, the climb finishes up a nice face. We found a way to do a NSR to get down, leaving no gear behind.
content.protection: Good pro in the horizontal breaks.
content.location: Park near Reardon's Rock and walk along the road toward the Rushmore parking lot. Walk the 30 second approach to the Northeast side of the Oval Office.

content.description: Andrew and I were climbing the routes on the Oval Office to document them for his guidebook when we stumbled across this gem. We couldn’t believe it had not been done, so the next day we put it up. Of course that was in July , I was just breaking into the 5.11 realm on granite and being west facing, trying to redpoint this guy was very challenging! I got a lot of Frequent Flyers Miles under my belt on this one!    If your in the Office definitely get your boarding pass and jump on!
content.protection: Green Alien-#3,stoppers, one bolt   Bolted anchors
content.location: This route is located on the west side of the Office. Look for the beautiful finger/hand crack.   West facing, friction dependant, plan your trip accordingly.

content.description: Flight over booked? Jump on a different one. Climb the original hand /finger crack but instead of clipping the bolt on the left, sling your last pieces and cast off to the crack on the right. After finding the sweet spot you can slot a good stopper and clip one bolt over the lip, you have now entered the Heartbreak crux!
content.protection: Stoppers, Green Alien to #3 Cammalot. One bolt. Chain anchors.
content.location:
Same start as Air Force One.

West facing, friction  dependent crux, plan your trip accordingly.

content.description: This  beautiful granite formation is a stones throw across Hwy 244 west of the Mount Rushmore Memorial parking area.  Development in this area started in 1984 and as of today there are only trad and mixed climbing. Most of the routes are on the north face so shade all day. A few test pieces face west so keep that in mind when jumping on them.
